bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to H.C. Woodfall, October 26, 1921

div1.p: Carter gives Woodfall advice on proposed legislation to control spread of malaria.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to H.C. Woodfall, October 26, 1921
div1.opener:
Impounded Waters
Please Return
H. R. Carter
Georgia
COPY
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.,
Oct. 26, 1921.
Dear Mr. Woodfall,-
div1.p:
Your letter of Oct. 22, 1921 received with
enclosure.

1. It seems to me that it might be well to divide your
Sec. 5 into two: One for the requirements before the pond is
filled and the other for the after care of the pond. This last
is as important as the first; it may be more so. This is how-
ever probably of no great importance.

2. Your provision for clean edges and fish control for
small and moderate sized ponds is practical and advisable -
indeed necessary. They are generally close to a considerable
population & their edges large in proportion to area; hence more breeding & less
wave action proportionally, than in large ponds.

3. You know however that to keep the edges of large
ponds - that of Lock #17 Black Warrior, Ala. had a shore line of
about 225 miles - is economically impossible. Whether there are
liable to be such ponds in Anopheles (A.quad.) producing parts
of Georgia I do not know, and if so whether this should be re-
quired of them by law is a question for Georgia to determine.
It would probably be as cheap to buy the land within the distance
of flight from the pond. This, however, would not free the pond
owners from the penalties of this act, even if - the country be-
ing vacated - no malaria is caused.

4. To what extent the methods or the details of the
methods to accomplish the purpose of a law should be expressed
in the law itself is always a question.

My own feeling is that this should be done as little as
may be: That in the law itself only such methods should be pre-
scribed of the expediency of enforcing which there is not any
doubt and concerning which we are quite sure that increased know-
ledge will not lead to a change of view. Such of course may and,
I think, should be expressed.

In addition the Act should express its purpose and
authorize the H. O. to carry it out by such regulations and orders
as may be necessary to do so, I think the Act of Congress of
February 1893 - the organic Act for the Maritime system of the
U. S. was established - is as near a model of this kind of law as
I know.

If I can find it I will send you the memorandum, fixed
up for Virginia by the H.O., Engineer and myself. Also one for
the Badin pond and one drawn up for Gen'l Beach, Chief of Engi-
neers U. S. Army, at his request for the general use for pools
formed in the improvement of navigation. Lock #8 of the Coosa
is the one he had immediately in view but the mem. is general.
These are by no means for incorporation in any law - too much
detail of method - but may be of use to you in making subsequent
regulations.

5. In my experience large bodies of impounded water in
the malaria section have always made some malaria. True they
also destroy same. Some, as at Baldin, destroy more by flooding
breeding places than they make elsewhere. Generally the contrary
is the case.

6. Anopheles production from a pond, large pond, has
also always been worse the first few (two?) years.

1. There is more floatage the first year or so and
thus more protection of Larvae from fish.

2. It takes about 3 years to kill the land vegetation
which standing on the edges acts the same way.

3. The banks are out sharp by wave action within a
few years, which acts both by draiowning the larvae and by removing
this protection against fish.

4. And finally the numuers, if minnows, small at first,
increase until the pond is stocked to its biologic equilibrium.

Everyone will admit that the complaint of malaria from a
pond lessens after the first few years. I think the malaria it-
self does. I have to draw a distinction between the two because
the hope of getting damages for malaria caused by the pond is un-
questionably a factor - the effect of which it is difficult to
estimate - in the complaint of pond-made malaria.

Pardon so long a letter. I have possibly not helped you
much in formulating your Act. I do not know your local conditions,
sociological, legal, or even topographical, but I think if you
read the enclosed memoranda you may find some points you can util-
ize.

Please return the enclosures marked “Return” as I have
no other copies of them.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, (Signed) H. R. Carter.
